page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY-COITY CASTLE
page.content: In the heart of Coity village stands the ruin of Coity Castle. It was built by the Turberville Family in the l2th century. When William lst ordered The Domesday Book to be written the chief man in Coity was Morgan ap Meurig. He lived in the court house (where the ruin of the castle now stands) with his beautiful daughter Sarah. After Robert Fitzhammon had conquered Cardiff he sent Payn de Turberville, one of his fiercest knights to claim the land around Coity. To avoid any fighting with the well-armed Norman soldiers, Morgan offered Payn the hand of his daughter Sarah. Payn and Sarah were married and there was no blood shed in Coity. The castle was occupied by the Turbervilles from 1100-1360 and was last used by the Gamage family.
